item.title: Moving slowly and (not) breaking things
item.description:
Iâ€™m not the worldâ€™s most patient person. I have a lot of ideas, and I always want to do everything immediately. I talk too fast. Honestly, Iâ€™m not even great at waiting thirty minutes for dinner.

But living in Portugal hasâ€”sort of accidentallyâ€”taught me patience. Everything takes longer than I expect here. Iâ€™ve been working at renovating our garage bathroom for monthsâ€”a task I claimed would be â€œcheap and fastâ€ back in Januaryâ€”and Iâ€™m only just now ready to install the plasterboard walls.

There are many reasons itâ€™s taken so longâ€”Iâ€™ve been making it up as I go, the home centre is incapable of delivering anything on time, I already have a day job, and that one time a ceiling collapsed full of dry rot. But every time I have to push things back yet again and I think to myself how I could be done by now if I just didnâ€™t bother building out that nicheâ€”I remember how badly things tend to go if I rush them needlessly.

Iâ€™m always grateful when Iâ€™ve taken the extra time to do a good job, no matter how painful it is to introduce yet another delay just because you have termites to deal with now too or you just really need a damned nap. (I really need a damned nap. And for my house to stop having major catastrophes on a weekly basis.)

Moving fast breaks things

And not to extrapolate too much, but I feel like this really applies to working in technology as well. Matt and I have both worked in tech for long enough to get pretty jaded. Thereâ€™s a lot to love about the tech industry, but thereâ€™s also a whole lot thatâ€™s broken about it too, and that has serious knock-on effects for the world at large.

Tech has long proclaimed the virtue of â€œmoving fast and breaking thingsâ€, a concept popularised by Facebookâ€”a company known for their upstanding morals and innovative design (â€¦right?) Thatâ€™s all well and good when all that youâ€™re breaking is your own servers, but itâ€™s just wilful ignorance to claim thatâ€™s as far as technology reaches into our lives.

Be NASA, not Facebook

Instead of moving fast and breaking things, we aim to move thoughtfully and fix things. We donâ€™t want to be Facebook. We want to be Margaret Hamilton, the absolute conker of a woman who sent a rocket to the fucking moon without a single bug, way before Facebook decided to destroy the fabric of society.

Itâ€™s easy to be impatientâ€”I get it. But itâ€™s so easy to fall into the trap of responding to everything with a kneejerk reaction and failing to follow through, especially with a twenty-four hour news cycle and social media that rewards us for talkingâ€”not for listening.

What weâ€™re up to now

So right now, weâ€™re taking our time, and trying to be thoughtful. Things arenâ€™t moving as fast as Iâ€™d like, but I hope that means weâ€™re doing better, more thoughtful work that actually helps people.

Weâ€™re currently hard at work on Turnip, our timer for freelancers and other people who need to track the time they spend working on projects. Weâ€™ve been using an internal version ourselves for over a year now, and itâ€™s almost ready for its betaâ€”but not quite. Weâ€™d been hoping for an April release, but then our ceiling caved in and now it might be more like May.

Somewhere along the line I wound up completely redesigning the interface and branding (weâ€™re not even at a beta yet and itâ€™s already on its third logo), and Matt completely overhauled the technical architecture. Iâ€™m not even sure itâ€™s the same thing we started working on a year ago, at our hack weekend to Aberdeen we cancelled two days before the first UK lockdown started, because it seemed irresponsible to go anywhere.

But Iâ€™m sure it will be better, and thatâ€™s something that my impatient heart can wait for.

item.title: Hooray! Everything is terrible.
item.description:
I hate to admit this, but Iâ€™m a glass half empty kind of girl. For a long time, Candide was my favourite book. Some days I wake up feeling like something terrible is going to happen. I keep my expectations tempered. Iâ€™d rather be suprised when things go right than gutted when they donâ€™t.

Iâ€™d like to be more optimistic. Optimists live longer, make better choices, are more resilient against psychological stressors, and just generally handle their shit better. But optimism is one of those things thatâ€™s baked into your genes and your history, and whilst you can, apparently, become more optimistic, most of us are wired a certain way and tend to stay there. So I guess Iâ€™m kind of a pessimist.

Matt, on the other hand, is the quintessential optimistâ€”a bouncing, joyful golden retriever for whom every day is sunny, even if itâ€™s raining out.

This difference between us has been especially prominent over the last year, as the world has been increasingly chaotic. I was convinced thereâ€™d be no more travel for a long time (points me) and Matt would swear a vaccine would be available soon (points Matt).

In many ways, weâ€™re polar opposites who approach the world through entirely different lenses. Heâ€™s calm whilst Iâ€™m exuberant verging on manic. I like building things, he takes pleasure in using a demolition hammer. He tends to focus on details whilst Iâ€™m more conceptual. I love starting projects and he likes to actually finish them.

Before we started Octopus Think, I spent eight years running a business solo, and it would have been extremely challenging for me to imagine ever having shared responsibility and control of the business with another human being.

But Matt and I have been doing this thing together for over a year now, whilst living basically in the same room, 24/7, and we just donâ€™t clash that often.

Itâ€™s these different outlooks that really mean we work well togetherâ€”both personally and professionally. We have many complementary skills, but we donâ€™t really have a huge amount of overlap. Together, we cover a lot of ground without really butting heads. We intersect just enough to have a shared understanding of what weâ€™re working toward.

And in the areas where our Venn diagrams connect, there tends to be a clear sense of ownership. For instance, I know some JavaScript (my chart above is a lie), but this is so clearly Mattâ€™s domain that I donâ€™t feel the need to argue with him if he tells me Iâ€™m doing something wrong. (Heâ€™s making what I can only assume are React jokes as I write this, but they arenâ€™t very funny.)

We spend a ridiculous amount of time discussing everything in great detail, from how we spend the businessâ€™ money to how we design an interface. We often go on long walks and discuss some aspect of what weâ€™re working on. By the time we get backâ€”often hours laterâ€”we both have a more nuanced understanding of the problem weâ€™re trying to solve, and how to solve it. I call these â€œargumentsâ€, but Mattâ€”ever the semantic nitpickerâ€”warns me that makes it sound like weâ€™re bickering. He calls them â€œdebatesâ€ or â€œdiscussionsâ€. Sure. ğŸ˜‰

Whatever you call them, theyâ€™re critical to us working well together. We come to better conclusions in spite of what might be otherwise limited experience, because weâ€™re considering a wider breadth of perspective than either of us could do alone. This is likely part of why diverse teams perform better. Itâ€™s also why, were we ever in the position to hire someone, weâ€™d prioritise someone whose lived experience was far from our own. (Yet another subject discussed via a long walk.)

So when my inherent pessimism collides with Mattâ€™s unbridled optimism, I think it actually gives us a more complete, more nuanced outlook on the world.

Together, weâ€™re uplifted enough to imagine a better future, to drive toward new work, and to continue forging ahead even when things get difficultâ€”but weâ€™re also critical enough to identify when something isnâ€™t working, when we need to reconsider an approach, or when a decision could potentially cause harm. I used to refer to us, together, as a cautious optimist. I think a better term might be a critical optimist.

Thereâ€™s no time like the present for critical optimism. There are signals that maybe, just maybe, the world is turning a number of corners toward a better futureâ€”but we also need to be mindful of all the forces that got us here in the first place. Especially those of us working in technology.

It might be the best of all possible worldsâ€¦ but letâ€™s really examine it critically first, just to be sure, okay?

item.title: The year in review: 2020
item.description:
Every month, Matt and I have a â€œmonthly summitâ€, which we schedule for the 8th at 8pm (we are really into the octopus theme, okay?). It may seem silly to have an â€œall-handsâ€ when youâ€™re two people living in the same house, but itâ€™s really helpful to regularly review what weâ€™ve done wellâ€”and what we havenâ€™t.

I often think New Yearsâ€™ lists are a bit played out. But I like the thought that, in ten yearsâ€™ time, weâ€™ll have an archive to look back on.

So, with that in mindâ€”hereâ€™s some of the high (and low!) lights of this especially tumultuous year:

ğŸš We moved to Portugal (and bought an old house)

We really didnâ€™t intend to move during a pandemicâ€”but Brexit meant that our time was running out for a project weâ€™d been planning for years. When it seemed like things were at their calmest, we packed everything we could on Mattâ€™s motorbike and drove through Scotland, England, Spain, and Portugal as quickly as we could. We spent nearly two whole days in a tiny room on the ferry, which was actually more pleasant than it sounds.

We wound up falling in love with an abandoned house from the 1700s that a local viscondessa had built for her servant/paramour, in a charming little village near some stunning hiking routes. The house needs a lot of love (there wasnâ€™t even running water when we moved in), but weâ€™re slowly working on bringing it back to life.

Learning Portuguese, making the house liveable, and dealing with mountains of paperwork, has consumed a great deal of our time and energy this year. Right now, we have running water and super-fast internet, but weâ€™re still working on hot water and a functional roof. Itâ€™s an uphill battle, but Portugal is beautiful, the people are friendly, and thereâ€™s lots of pasteis de nata to keep us full of sugar energy while we demolish things. ğŸ˜‹

ğŸš€ We shipped our first app

We released Mic Drop, our mic-muting app for Macs in early 2020, right after lockdowns started in earnest, which seemed like fortuitous timing.

It was featured on MacRumors in June, which lead to a giant spike in sales and was really cool! Releasing and supporting an app is an exhausting, but exhilarating, process. Weâ€™ve learnt so much about all sort of different things, from pricing and marketing an app (still not a major skillset) to dealing with oddities of macOS APIs.

Feedback has been overwhelmingly positive, and doing all of our own support on a product we directly control has meant weâ€™ve been able to fix bugs quickly and improve the app thoughtfully.

ğŸ˜¢ We didnâ€™t ship as many apps as we wanted to

Our original intention was to ship an app every quarter. That obviously hasnâ€™t happened yetâ€”we only shipped one (Mic Drop) and our second (Turnip) is nearly ready for beta. As it turns out, shipping even a super simple app is an absolute boatload of work, and everything took more time than weâ€™d expected. We also spent a great deal of time on client work, volunteer work, and personal stuff (see: moving during a pandemic).

Thatâ€™s okayâ€”weâ€™ll get faster in the future as we know more and have more infrastructure built up, and ultimately weâ€™d much rather release fewer, higher-quality apps. We always want to take the time to be thoughtful about our decisions, and if that makes things take longer, thatâ€™s okay.

Hopefully next year weâ€™ll be able to double our productivity and release two.

ğŸš§ We had our first (and only) hack weekend

Weâ€™d planned to do hack weekends once a quarter. A great excuse to go visit a new place, get into a new headspace, and do some heads-down work on a new project (or really focus on improving an existing project!)

We planned our first for a long weekend in Aberdeen in March, and then very suddenly the UK went into lockdown and we couldnâ€™t go anywhere. We stayed home instead and got lots of work done. It wasnâ€™t quite what weâ€™d envisioned, but we managed to build an alpha of Turnip that weâ€™ve been using on our machines ever since.

Our hope for 2020 is for more of these focussed, intensive work sessionsâ€”even if we can only do them from our currently-unheated office.

We launched 13 new client sites

Our regular client work took up a lot of time this yearâ€”there was lots of work that needed doing! We worked with a number of different charitable organisations focused on providing relief to various sectors impacted by the pandemic and to promoting social justice.

We also worked with the Scottish Tech Army to design & build Open Texts, a project from the National Library of Scotland dedicated to making the digital collections of public libraries around the world more accessibleâ€”basically a search engine for free books. We did this work for free as volunteers because it seemed an awesome project to be able to give our expertise to. It was a super fun project to work on, especially for booky creatures such as ourselves. (Mostly me. I have a book problem.)

We started making charitable donations

We released Mic Drop in April, right around where everyone was suddenly being forced to work remotely. The timing was accidental, but we were aware that we might benefit from that bump. Of course, we want our business to be successful, but that doesnâ€™t mean holding onto every dollar whilst others are suffering.

So we decided to donate 50% of all Mic Drop revenues to charitable organisations impacted by the pandemic. We donated Â£667.60 donated to Scottish Womenâ€™s Aid and Â£306.38 to the Scottish Refugee Council, and we have one last cheque to make out once our numbers for Q4 are in.

For 2021, weâ€™d like to continue this habit, but tying the values to our overall profits, rather than just a single product.

Goals for next year

We like to keep our goals measureable and concrete:

  • Donate at least 1% of profits to charitable causes
  • Ship two new apps
  • Hold four hack weekends
  • Publish ten blog posts

So this year, we didnâ€™t accomplish all our goals, and thatâ€™s okay. We did make it out the other end in mostly one piece, and we strengthened our personal and professional relationships whilst laying groundwork for what we hope will be a better year to come.

Oh and hey, we managed to get our â€œyear-in-reviewâ€ post out before the year had technically ended this time, so thatâ€™s definitely progress. ğŸ˜œ

item.title: A watched employee never boils
item.description:
I was on the hunt for a job when I found it. â€œMust install Time Doctor on computer,â€ it said. â€œReports will be sent to your manager every week.â€

Appalled, I closed the tab. Sure, I wanted a job, but there was no way Iâ€™d be willing to let my employer spy on me. Who would?

Fast-forward to today, where suddenly a whole lot of us are remote workers, whether we want to be or not. Remote work seems to be here to stay. But traditional employers, accustomed to being able to look over their employeesâ€™ shoulders constantly, arenâ€™t quite ready to adopt to a new way of working.

Instead, theyâ€™re trying to be everywhere at once. Demanding your webcam be on all day. Scheduling multiple daily check-ins. Mandatory socialisation time. Requiring you install an app on your phone to track your movements. Thereâ€™s a booming business in work surveillance apps, and every one of them sounds horribly creepy and invasive: taking photos of your screen (or your face) every five seconds, logging your keystrokes, recording the apps and websites you use, and ranking you based on your â€œproductivityâ€.

Itâ€™s 1984 out there. Employees, not surprisingly, are stressed out.

The office may actually be more of a distraction

Hereâ€™s the thing: if youâ€™re worried someone wonâ€™t get any work done at home, donâ€™t worry: they donâ€™t get any work done at the office either.

Fun fact: the first (and last!) time I had an office job, I was guilty of at least once falling asleep at my desk. In an open office. Nobody ever noticed.

But itâ€™s not just me being lazy! Office workers say they spend just three hours a day on productive work, and as much as three hours on personal tasks. (The rest is emails and meetings, which letâ€™s not even get started on.)

Just because weâ€™re sitting in the office doesnâ€™t mean weâ€™re working. Weâ€™re watching Tiger King, playing Angry Birds, emailing our friends, doomscrolling through Twitter, and even perusing porn. (Yep. A solid 70% of traffic to porn sites happens during the day.)

A recent survey of COVID-induced remote workers actually shows that people are more productive when working from home and they experience almost half as many distractions as they do when in the office. Apparently your children are less disruptive than your coworkers.

Hours â‰  results

Our eight-hours-a-day model isnâ€™t even the best way to get work done effectively.

Historically, we worked way more than 40 hours a week in manufacturing jobs. Working hours progressively tapered off over the years, thanks to pressure from unions, until they landed at 40 hours in the 1930s and thenâ€¦ they just kinda got stuck there. Plenty of studies found that 8 hours a day was optimal to avoid burnout in manufacturing jobs, but we never bothered to update it for a shift to knowledge work, where we have fewer productive hours in a day.

Lots of historically productive people only worked a few hours a day, spending the rest of their time going for walks, reading, or even napping.

Science backs them up. (Thanks, science!) A study of violin students found that the best students werenâ€™t those who put in more hours, but rather those who studied more deliberately, engaging fully rather than just slogging through hours. And it found that kind of deliberate study was best done in short bursts, followed by breaksâ€”adding up to only four hours a day. Another study in the 1950s found that scientists were most productive when they worked 20 hours a week.

Numerous studies indicate that wasting time actually makes you more, not less, productive. As it turns out, rest and breaks are as integral to getting quality work done as time spent actively working.

Maybe Iâ€™m just a slacker?

Having spent most of my grown-up life as a freelancer, Iâ€™ve spent a lot of time closely tracking how I spend my time. Back when I was running my first business, I often worked sixty hour work weeks, in between club-hopping. (I didnâ€™t sleep a lot.)

When I took a remote job, I stopped tracking my time, and switched to focussing on a healthier work-life balance. Iâ€™d work a few hours in the morning, when everything was quiet (working from Europe with primarily US-based colleagues makes for a really productive, focussed morning work session). Then Iâ€™d take a long break in the afternoon. Iâ€™d go play squash when the courts were empty, or pop to the shops when the queues were nonexistent. In the evening, Iâ€™d return to work and connect synchronously with coworkers.

Now, I find I struggle to work an eight-hour day with any regularity. I track my time pretty closelyâ€”if Iâ€™m working, thereâ€™s a timer running, but if Iâ€™m browsing shoes on the internet, I pause it. Some days I get on a roll and accidentally work 11 hours. But most of the time, I find myself actually working closer to an average of 25-30 hours a week.

So whatâ€™s the solution?

Treat your employees like adults. Micro-managing, in any context, is actively detrimental to productivity, and it promotes a fear-based style of leadership. When employees are given autonomy, theyâ€™re happier, more engaged, and they often come up with better results. Bonus: theyâ€™re less likely to up and quit.

Lead with trust. Rather than focussing on a model where employees are guilty by default, begin by extending full trust. (After all, you wouldnâ€™t have hired them if you didnâ€™t think they were great, right?) When people are handed responsibility, theyâ€™re more likely to rise to the challenge. If you lead by mistrusting them, theyâ€™re more likely to think of ways to subvert your surveillance system.

Focus on outcomes, not time. There are lots of great reasons to track your time, but ultimately, time just isnâ€™t a great measure of what someoneâ€™s actually doing. Instead, try to focus on what theyâ€™ve accomplished. OKRs (objectives and key results) are one way of doing this, but there are lots of structured approaches to measure employee productivity in a non-time-based way. Rather than doing yearly check-ins, check in more frequently in order to nip any problems in the bud.

Encourage breaks. This may sound counter-productive, but the actual danger of remote working is never being able to turn off. As the boundaries between work and home blur, it becomes easier to overwork, or check in constantly, which can actually be counter-productive. Encourage employees to take breaks and work when theyâ€™re most productive. If necessary, have â€œon-callâ€ times when everyoneâ€™s expected to be around. But recognise that workers will often be more productive (and happier!) if they can take breaks during the day, or if they can fit work around their schedules.

â€¦and what if youâ€™re an employee, hit by some draconian measures?

Hit us up, we can write you a bot to make it look like youâ€™re working. ğŸ˜

item.title: How to mute a mic in six months
item.description:
Thereâ€™s an undeniable appeal in simplicity, especially as technology feels increasingly complex. The products we love the most are often the ones that feel the simplest, even if they arenâ€™t necessarily the ones that do the least.

From a consumer perspective, this often creates something of a paradoxâ€”when an app feels simple, we think that it must have been simple to build, but often, the inverse is true. Building an app that feels simple for users can often require more work under the hood than it would to build a more complex app, because weâ€™re managing that complexity in the code, rather than asking the user to handle that complexity for us.

Thatâ€™s good for usersâ€”but not so great for us, when we just wanna ship our damned app! ğŸ˜…

If I had more time, Iâ€™d write a shorter letter

Mic Drop is a macOS menubar app that allows you to mute and unmute your microphone with a keyboard shortcut. The goal of the app is to provide a customisable, easy, and reliable way to control your microphone in remote meetings and calls.

Mic Dropâ€™s core functionalityâ€”muting the microphoneâ€”is simple to describe but complex to implement. Itâ€™s the perfect example of developer hubris: â€Easy. I could build it in a week!â€ Thatâ€™s what I thought too.

In November. (Note: We released Mic Drop in April.) ğŸ˜…

To mute the microphone, Mic Drop relies on macOSâ€™s Core Audio framework. Itâ€™s a set of APIs that controls low-level audio device functionality on Macs. Itâ€™s been around for a long time, and as a result itâ€™s pretty complex and certainly very-edge-case-y.

It turns out managing inputs like microphones is much more complicated than we thought! From aggregate inputs and loopback devices, not every input device is a real microphone. There are microphones that ignore mute settings, and some that claim to honour mute status but donâ€™t. (Iâ€™m looking at you, LG UltraFine 5K.)

Thereâ€™s a whole lot of code for handling edge cases in Mic Drop!

Letâ€™s not reinvent the wheel

We built on top of existing open-source libraries to handle recording keyboard shortcuts. Weâ€™ve shared these customised versions of these libraries so you can use them in your own projects.

We published an Under the Hood page on the Mic Drop website. This is something weâ€™ll be doing for all future appsâ€”partly because weâ€™re curious, and partly because weâ€™re fans of transparency. It allows us an opportunity to explain our choices and gives others a reference for their own projects. ğŸ“•

It turns out itâ€™s one of the most popular pages on the Mic Drop website, so either people are curious or theyâ€™re finding it useful. Weâ€™ll definitely stick with the habit.

Weâ€™re also using Microsoftâ€™s App Center to log (anonymous!) usage stats and crash metrics for users who opt-in. Itâ€™s easy to use, and comes with a dead-simple API for logging events in the app. Iâ€™d recommend it! ğŸ‘ğŸ»

On macOSâ€”and the Mac App Store

Weâ€™re web people at heart, and though weâ€™ve made iOS and Android apps in the past, this is the first macOS app weâ€™ve shipped. Itâ€™s also the first app we sold via the Mac App Store.

At first, we werenâ€™t even sure if we would ship Mic Drop to the Mac App Storeâ€”but Iâ€™m glad we did.

Itâ€™s frustrating to be paying \$99/year and 30% to Appleâ€”a company famed for their excellent user experienceâ€”and then have Appleâ€™s review process block us from shipping bug fixes to users, sometimes for lengthy periods of time. ğŸ˜¤

I know App Store review times have improved a good deal, but the unnecessary opaqueness of the process and the comparison to the ease of self-publishing updates is a needless frustration.

That said: we canâ€™t deny that the Mac App Store has benefitted app sales. This month Mic Drop has made about 50% of its revenue via the App Store, and we get some sales from organic searches via the app store.

Singing to myself

Building an audio app makes for some strange development habits. Sometimes I sing into the microphone with a VU meter open to see if the mute is working. Sarah has just learnt to ignore the chorus of â€œDo do do dee dee do deeâ€ streaming from the office. ğŸ¶

There was a bug related to a menubar API when multiple monitors were used with a MacBook screen open. Since I have a single-monitor setup at my desk, I had to get creative to reproduce the issue:

So many Vespas! ğŸ›µ (Including on my coffee cup.)

Hardware is hard

Testing meeting software is easy. Most meeting apps have a free version we can test with.

But not all audio hardware behaves consistently, and itâ€™s a real pain to diagnose issues without the hardware on hand. A lot of the hardware people write in about is expensive and niche, so itâ€™s often quite costly to test an issue for one user. We try really hard to offer great support, but the maths on that is trickyâ€”a Â£500 device for a Â£4 sale (of which weâ€™re donating Â£2, and the taxman takes nearly Â£1) is the kind of business practise that makes our accountant give us long lectures.

I wonâ€™t lie: weâ€™ve (ab)used generous return policies a few times, because we donâ€™t personally have much use for a Â£500+ USB-XLR Audio interface after weâ€™ve debugged its issues. ğŸ˜†

Betas are the best

Iâ€™d be remiss if I didnâ€™t mention some of the awesome and creative users weâ€™ve met during Mic Dropâ€™s early development. â¤ï¸

This was our first Mac app and weâ€™re a young company, so our beta group was pretty small. But those users provided really excellent feedback. Even if your beta group is tiny, itâ€™s worth doing to get any feedback you can and ensure your app works for people before you ship it to the world!

One of our beta users (hi Enrique! ğŸ‘‹ğŸ») shared feedback that, after some discussion with Sarah, led to the status window feature. I was skeptical at first, but itâ€™s turned out to be a very popular feature. Heck, even I use it now! ğŸ™ƒ

Another user was building an Arduino-powered â€œOn Airâ€ light switch to hook up to a keyboard shortcut for Mic Drop. Pretty cool! (Send photos, please!) ğŸ’¡

Greener pastures (in defense of the web)

I often hear developers bemoan the amount of technology needed to build even a simple â€œHello worldâ€ web app. From transpiling ES6 with Babel to managing assets with Webpack: thereâ€™s a lot to learn to make a good website these days. Gone are the days of â€œwrite some HTML, CSS, and maybe some jQueryâ€ to build a website or an HTML app. But itâ€™s backward to observe this trend and proclaim: The web is getting too complex because the build systems are complex! The reality is those build systems are evolving at the same rate as the web itself, which can do a lot more than it could it the days of jQuery 1.0.

Venture into Xcode and youâ€™ll observe the same sort of complexity. Except itâ€™s obscured by an IDE and a lack of open-source code. Say what you will about the web, but you can always go to the source if neededâ€”and with the functional and modular approach more build tools and libraries are taking, you arenâ€™t locked into a development paradigm like you were in the days of WordPress or Rails. Conversely, Xcode and the Apple toolchain are pretty much the only way to build a macOS app aside from Electron.

All of this is just to say that the grass is always greener. Xcode can be frustrating, opaque, and restrictive. It comes a steep learning curve. I had plenty of â€œoh, cool!â€ moments building Mic Drop, but my frustrations with Xcode were similar to the frustrations I encounter with any new tool. ğŸ¤·ğŸ»â€â™‚ï¸

Once more unto the breach

After all that: would we do it all over again? We sure would! In fact: weâ€™ve already started!

Weâ€™re currently busy working on another menu bar app, except this one will be for both macOS and Windows. Itâ€™s a timer app, for freelancers and other people who need to track the time they spend working on projects. Itâ€™s currently especially designed for users of FreeAgent, but weâ€™re planning other integrations and a standalone version as well.

If you want to hear more about it sign up for our newsletter (at the bottom of the page) or follow us on Twitter to get notified when we start the beta!

item.title: The Remote Meeting Etiquette Guide
item.description:
Matt and I have been working remotely for over a decade, so weâ€™ve seen it all when it comes to video call snafus. Want to ace your video meetings and nab that promotion? Follow our simple guide!

1. Always wear bottoms.

Hey, we get it. Your co-workers can only see you from the waist up. Why not, right? Nobody will ever know the difference!

Wrong.

This is just a risk you donâ€™t need to take. Put some trousers on, please!

2. Send your lover(s) packing.

Ideally, youâ€™re going to want to keep your unintentional nudes to a strict minimum.

If you happen to be stepping out on a significant other who isnâ€™t cool with it, maybe that â€œstrict minimumâ€ should be closer to â€œzeroâ€.

3. Make sure your decor is appropriate.

Matt worked with someone for several years who continually attended video calls withâ€¦ â€œeroticâ€ art behind him, always in frame. Not to be a prude, but maybe leave that for the after-work social video call.

Hot tip: your pre-meeting prep should always include opening up Photo Booth (or some other camera app) and checking to see whatâ€™s in frame. This is also an excellent opportunity to make sure your hair looks good and you arenâ€™t at a super weird angle. (I like to prop my laptop up on a pile of cookbooks so itâ€™s aimed straight at my face, rather than angled up like Iâ€™m some sort of demi-god. YMMV.)

4. Lock your door.

Children: lifeâ€™s little embarrassing moment machines.

5. Turn off your mic before cussing out your colleagues.

Almost every single day, I wind up in a meeting with someone silently mouthing words at their screen, and I have to interrupt them with a â€œSorry, youâ€™re muted!â€

We wanted a simple app that did a few things really well:

  • Shows your mute status in the Mac menu bar.

  • Supports mute toggle, push-to-talk, and push-to-mute.
  • Keeps track of all of your devices.

That last one is a big one if you travel and do meetings with wireless headphones. (True story.)

How does it work?

Mic Drop allows you to record a custom keyboard shortcut to toggle your microphone. You can use it anytimeâ€”in any appâ€”to mute or unmute your microphone. No matter what youâ€™re doing, it just works.

It keeps track of your input devices to make sure theyâ€™re muted, but Mic Drop never listens to you or records your input. Why do I need this?

item.description:

Where we fell short

Remove it!â€ Itâ€™s easy to fall into the trap of the never-ending to-do list, but there are a few things I wish weâ€™d done better.

item.title: Making ethics the beating heart(s) of our business
item.description:
One sunny morning earlier this year, Matt and I made a giant pot of Chemex and conducted a series of exercises to determine our brand. Covering our newly-tiled kitchen walls with post-it notes helped us better understand our shared values, priorities, and motivators. A theme that kept coming up was ethics.

Weâ€™ve both spent a long time working for big tech companies, watching technology become more interwoven in peopleâ€™s everyday lives. Many of these changes are improvements for the better, but others have the potential to create harm. The tech industry often gets so excited about what we can do that we sometimes donâ€™t stop to ask ourselves if we should do it.

We want to make the tech industry a more diverse and ethical place. We genuinely believe that technology is a tool to improve peopleâ€™s lives, and that itâ€™s more and more important that we wield it carefully, thoughtfully, and deliberately.

Itâ€™s all well and good saying we care about ethics, or signing whatever pledge might be making the rounds this week, or putting a #TechForGood hashtag on all our tweets. But if we donâ€™t back that up with a clear and concrete declaration of what that actually means in practise, itâ€™s just ethics-washing. (I made that up right now. Feel free to use it.)

So weâ€™ve established some guidelines for what our ethics are and what that means in practise. And weâ€™re making it public, because that keeps us accountable.

These ethical stances underpin every decision we make. It means we have long discussions about the suppliers and services we use. It means we balance cost and features with impact on the world. We arenâ€™t ascetic about it, but we aim to make the best decisions possible. We donâ€™t do anything without thinking about it.

Three is a lovely auspicious number. Thereâ€™s three wishes, three little pigs, three musketeers, a holy trinity (or two), three witches, three Fatesâ€”and itâ€™s a helpful number for making things beautiful, balanced, or hilarious, as seen by the rule of thirds, the rule of three, or any other three-rule.

Octopuses have three hearts, so we do too. (Metaphorically, of course.)

Inclusion

Inclusion is at the core of everything that we do. Technology has the power to be a social equaliser, but often new technical developments can serve to exclude, isolate, or silence people. Using historically corrupted data to teach a machine leads to a computer thatâ€™s just as racist (or sexist, or ableist, or homophobicâ€¦) as history. We want to stop taking the â€œeasyâ€ route and instead think about the impact we have. This shit matters.

In practise, this means always thinking about the different types of users who will be affected by our technical decisions. We use persona spectrums and consequence mapping. We design with accessibility at the forefront. We arenâ€™t rigid about how we ask for userâ€™s personal information, and we only ask when we have a good reason to do so. Our design system is rooted in inclusive principles and features accessible componentsâ€”itâ€™s also open source, so others can build on our work.

Respect

Respect means treating our users, clients, and anyone who our technology reaches the way weâ€™d like to be treated.

In practise, this means we avoid designing or implementing dark patterns. We put usersâ€™ privacy and security at the forefront. We donâ€™t trick, coerce, or manipulate people. We ask for permission and are clear about how weâ€™re using any data youâ€™ve chosen to entrust us with. We are open and transparent in everything we do, and how everything we build works. We donâ€™t take VC funding and instead bootstrap our work, ensuring our sole responsibility is to our customers.

Sustainability

When we think of sustainability, we think of both environmental and economic resilience. This widens our scope and allows us to think more broadly about how our business impacts the world we all inhabit. How are our individual choices, on both a personal and a profession level, impacting the world at large? Are we following campground rules?

In practise, this means weâ€™ve built a sustainable business model based on controlled and deliberate growth. We pay our taxes. Our primary responsibility is to our customers, not shareholders. We donâ€™t take work with Halliburton, Goldman Sachs, or Enron (not that theyâ€™re offering).

We consider the environmental impact of our work. Weâ€™re evaluating options for greener hosting and our VPS uses renewable energy. We build sites to be as performant as possible (this site loads in about one second!). We have a printer, but we donâ€™t use it all that much. We donâ€™t commute anywhere (or even own a car) and our home office uses 100% renewable energy. (It may or may not help that we live in the windiest country in Europe. ğŸ´ó §ó ¢ó ³ó £ó ´ó ¿)

How these hearts define our business

Everything we do is derived from these three pillars. Our values, brand, and design principles (more on all of these later) all tie back to our ethics. Every decision we makeâ€”whether to include a pop-up here, which analytics package to use, or whether to pursue a new contractâ€”is assessed through these lenses. Ethics arenâ€™t the only metrics by which we make our decisions, but theyâ€™re a hugely important component.

The tricky thing about ethicsâ€”and being public about those ethicsâ€”is thereâ€™s a risk you might get it wrong. Getting a fact wrong in public is one thing, but getting your ethics wrong is a whole other thing entirely. Reputations have been made and ruined (mostly ruined) by a misguided tweet.

Weâ€™re okay with that risk. We respect people enough to think theyâ€™ll understand when we get it wrong and that weâ€™re always learning. Weâ€™d rather try and fail than not try at all. We genuinely believe that by being as transparent as possible, we hold ourselves more accountable to our own standards.

So thatâ€™s where you come in! If you see us getting it wrong, or if weâ€™re failing to consider things fully, or if we could be making better decisions, let us know! We donâ€™t mind being wrong when itâ€™s an opportunity to improve our future selves. â¤ï¸â¤ï¸â¤ï¸
